Just as a data point, I wrote a NEAT engine in C++ a few years back for
the purposes of eventually teaching it poker.  I too was humbled by the
poker aspect when I started trying to reduce the input vector (which is of
course the hard part) to something of even close to a workable size. 
Capturing the state and historical state of the game all in a single
vector is of course extraordinarily difficult.  However, if someone can
figure out how to decompose the game even to a mid-sized input, I'd still
like to take a run at it.  The engine I wrote is very fast (as I figured
that would be the bottleneck work-wise).  As it turns out, the bottle neck
is more likely (in my opinion) the computation required for any meaningful
reduction of the input.  For example, a useful data point is probably the
probability any given hand will win at any given point in the game
assuming homogeneous players and homogeneous strategy.  This can easily be
calculated but it is work-intensive.  In fact, prohibitively so depending
on how you do it.  Of course, it is probably possible to approximate it,
but I never came up with a model for this.

I think some headway could be made but be prepared to spend a lot of time
coming up with a very light, very fast model for the game of poker that
you can use to evolve the machine.  Anything else will result in something
that never, ever converges.  If you make any progress, let me know.  I'd
be happy to work with someone on this!  Also, I posted my engine on the
NEAT groups but if someone wants it, let me know.  It is a great deal
faster than the C# implementations and could probably be even faster.

Best luck,

Jeff Haynes
